description:
On August 8, 2020 the Swiss FOPH updated the list of considered risk countries. As before (since July 6th) all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days at home or in a suitable accomodation, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Contact details are provided by flights or bus services selected at random. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.

description: On August 21, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced the collective quarantining of customers of a bar and students of a school due to positive corona cases. The collective quarantine was announced via SMS and lasts for 10 days.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On 25 August, the canton Bern, Switzerland, announces the positive tests of three Asylumseekers and refugees in Huttwil. The canton says that 45 people associated with the Refugees have been put into Quarantine. One of the persons who tested positive also went to a class at the Rudolf-Steiner-Schule. Therefore, that class has also been placed under quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine

description: On September 25th, 2020 the list of considered risk countries (valid from Sept 28th) was updated by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 days have to quarantine for 10 days ( at home or in a suitable accomodation). A negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation (except change of list after departure). They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are diplomats, transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions and  professionals re-entering after participating in an event like sports competition, cultural event, a specialist congress. risk countries as of September 28th: Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Armenia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Belgium, Belize, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Czechia, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guyana, Honduras, Hungary, Iceland, India, Iraq, Ireland, Israel, Jamaica, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Luxemburg, Maledives, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Morocco, Namibia, Nepal, Netherlands, North Macedonia, Palestine, Oman, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Qatar, Romania, Spain, Slovenia, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Ukraine, UAE, UK, USA.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:
At its meeting on March 6th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council adjusted its strategy  and focused on protecting particularly vulnerable people.  The FOPH has issued recommendations for the world of work: Absence from the workplace should be considered if no distancing or other temporary employment is possible for particularly vulnerable people who are exposed to an increased risk of infection in the workplace.
risk factors are: above 65 years of age, hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, an immune system weakened by disease or treatment, or cancer
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
At its meeting on March 6th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council adjusted its strategy. The FOPH has issued recommendations for the world of work: 
- Ensuring consistent compliance with personal hygiene measures (hand washing).
- Employees should, if operationally possible, keep their distance from one another e.g. by creating spatial adjustments, office splitting, teleworking / home office, etc. Masks are not recommended.
- Goodwill should apply when a doctor's certificate is requested. It should be requested from the 5th day at the earliest.
- Employers should make their employees' working hours as flexible as possible so that peak times in public transport can be avoided.
- Employees are to be informed of personal and workplace-related protective measures according to the current guidelines of the FOPH.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On March 15th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the closure of all non-essential (walk-in) businesses, effective on March 16th.
Essential businesses are allowed to remain open and are defined as the following: any shop that mostly sells essential goods, gas stations and associated shops, kiosks, newsstands, pharmacies, drugstores, pharmacies, banks and post offices. 

Exceptions are the following:
Non-essential businesses that are closed are allowed to receive some clients with appointments. 
Restaurants, shops and institutions are allowed to produce and distribute food that is meant for take away or delivery.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On March 17th the Canton Uri released an instruction to clarify how the measures by the federal government  are being implemented in the Canton. It withholds a restriction and regulation businesses implementing that food & medical suppliers can open, but most of the other businesses have to close

On March 16, 2020 at its extraordinary meeting the SwissFederal Council took the decision to introduce more stringent measures to protect the public. 
People at especially high risk should work from home. If that is not possible, they are to be placed on leave by their employers, but will continue to receive their pay. Employees make a personal statement about their particular risk. The employer can request a medical certificate.
risk factors issued by the FOPH are: above 65 years of age, hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, an immune system weakened by disease or treatment, or cancer

description:
The Swiss Federal council announces an extraordinary situation whereby all non-essential businesses must close by midnight on March 16th 2020 until April 19th. This policy was extended by one week till April 26th.
The Swiss federal council announced on April 16th a three-phase plan to re-open non-essential businesses starting on April 27th, followed by May 11th and ending on June 8th provided further decreasing case numbers.
type_sub_cat: Retail Businesses

description:
On March 18, 2020 the Federal Office of Health in Switzerland published guidelines on social distancing and hygiene for essential businesses that remain open after the closing of non-essential businesses on March 17:
- compliance with social distancing
- daily cleaning of handles and touched surfaces
- limiting the number of persons (customers and employees) to one person per 10 squaremeter





.

description: Switzerland, Geneva -- In response to the crisis caused by the coronavirus, the Department of Economic Development (DDE) is encouraging Geneva restaurants and businesses to develop their offer on the Internet, in order to ensure the supply of the population. As of 25 March, 2020, the DDE has released 100,000 francs to speed up the posting of menus for Geneva restaurants and access to home meal delivery services. This aid is paid in installments to the Socit des Cafetiers, Restaurateurs et Hteliers de Genve (SCRHG), which coordinates the distribution of funds. A fund of 50,000 francs has been allocated to the NODE (Nouvelle Organization Des Entrepreneurs), to strengthen the capacity of local e-commerce platforms to process new requests for integration into their website and thus rapidly increase the number of businesses and products available on the Internet.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On April 1, the COVID-19 leadership body (KFO) of the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced that the selling of seeds, saplings, and potting soil would be allowed under restrictions. These include to online-sales with delivery, drive-in systems with strict distancing and without causing traffic disruption, the closure of access to stores and greenhouses, mandatory orders in advance (online, via telephone or email), the avoidance of payments by cash, and the arrangement of exact timings to pick up the product. This measures eases the federal restriction of non-essential businesses from the 13 March 2020 due to the demand among the population.

description: On April 9, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg allowed the re-opening of markt stalls in public places under the following conditions: The measure only concerns stalls that sell groceries, the distance between stalls in public places needs to be between 50-80 meters, the staff needs to ensure physical distancing of 2 meters in the queue, municipalities decide the days when market stalls are allowed while usual opening times can be extended to reduce the numbers of customers, municipalities need to ensure fair treatment of all merchants, and the cantonal police will be controlling. When these conditions apply, market stalls can only be opened in places where usually markets take place regularly.

description:
On 24th April 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced a series of requirements for the partial reopening of businesses (scheduled by the Swiss Federal Council on 27th April 2020 - see the policy coded on the federal level). Businesses allowed to reopen have to define a protection scheme for clients and personnel in compliance with the federal recommendations. The scheme has to encompass hygiene and social distancing rules as well as protection for vulnerable populations. Controls will be conducted to ensure compliance with requirements. If the protection scheme is deemed insufficient, cantonal authorities can prevent a business to reopen. If a business doesn't comply with its protection scheme, cantonal authorities can force a business to close.

NB: the businesses allowed to reopen (according to the federal policy) are: personal grooming stores (hair salons, tattoo salons...), hardware stores, florists, garden centers and self-service businesses (carwash, plant nurseries...).
type_sub_cat: Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
In Switzerland on April 16, 2020 the Federal Council announced that as of April 27 following non-essential business will be allowed to reopen:
personal grooming ( hairdresser, massage studios, tattoo studios); garden center, florists and nurseries; Do-it-yourself shops; self-service facilities ( car-washing, solarium, pick-your-own-crops).
All business have to follow a protection protocoll including hygienic measures, hand sanitation for customers, allowing social distancing. For personal grooming masks are obligatory, in shops not more than one customer per 10 qm is allowed.
type_sub_cat: Commercial Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On April 29, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced the second step of easing business restrictions starting May 11. 
All shops, retail business and markets are allowed to reopen according to their protection concept ( one customers per 10 qm, compliance to the guidelines of the Federal Office of Health in regard of social distancing, hygiene).
Private museum and private libraries may open according to their protection concept.
Restaurants and bars can take the first step of resumption: only for seated consumption, groups of up to 4 per table, distance between tables, closure from midnight to 6 am, no live musik or events, masks recommended for employees

On May 12ve, 2020 the government council of Swiss canton Basel City is temporarily allowing Basel restaurateurs affected by the measures against the coronavirus to expand their existing outdoor seating. The expansion is possible immediately without a permit, as long as it meets the requirements (access for fire brigade, police...) and in particular the safety regulations. Expansions on the carriageway or on streets without sidewalks must be reported to the administration.The regulation applies until the distance rules are lifted due to the coronavirus, at the latest until November 15, 2020.

description:
In Switzerland, the canton Aargau will open from the May 12 on, all locations of the Museum Aargau. The castles Lenzburg, Wildegg, Hallwyl and Habsburg, the Vindonissa Legionnaire's Trail, the Vindonissa Museum and the Knigsfelden Monastery welcome visitors.
The Museum Aargau opens the locations in compliance with a protection concept that builds on the rules and regulations of the federal government. In addition to disinfectants and floor markings for the minimum distance, a limited number of visitors are allowed to enter the premises. Wherever possible, the entrances and exits as well as tours of the museum are separated by direction. Only a few areas in which the distance and hygiene rules (among other things for structural reasons) cannot be observed remain temporarily closed.

description:
On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council is easing most of the remaining business restrictions as of 6 June. 
All leisure and entertainment businesses such as casinos, amusement parks, cinema, theatre, discos may reopen, as can swimming pools and spas. Strip clubs may also reopen and services offered by sex workers may resume. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, e.g.by means of attendance lists.
For groups of more than four people restaurants it is required to take the contact details of one guest per table.Customers may still only be served when seated. All establishments, discos and nightclubs are required to close at midnight and may not admit more than 300 people a night. Discos are limited to one customer per 4 qm.
.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On June 19, the Federal Council of Switzerland announces that from June 22 until September 13 operators of publicly accessible establishments and businesses such as restaurants, bars, clubs and discotheques and dance venues must draw up and implement a precautionary measures plan. It must include measures relating to hygiene and social distancing. The following persons are exempted from maintaining the required distance of 1,5m: groups of pupils, families or persons of the same household. Otherwise guests have to wear a mask or other effective protective measures must be taken, such as erecting suitable barriers. In the case of seats arranged in rows or in a similar way, in particular in theatres, concert halls and cinemas, only every second seat or seats separated by an equivalent distance may be occupied. The contact details of the persons present must be recorded if it is possible that they will be unable to maintain the required distance for a period in excess of 15 minutes and other protective measures are not in place. The contact details must on request be passed on to the competent cantonal authority or organization for the purpose of identifying and notifying persons who may have been infected. If over 300 persons and a maximum of 1000 persons are present, they must be split into groups of 300 persons per sector. Violation will be punished by fines.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On July 8th, the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that bar, club and restaurant owners would have to identify and record all visitors and verify the provided data. Furthermore, the maximum number of visitors would be limited to 100 if neither social distancing nor hygienic measures could be enforced. However, multiple seperated rooms for 100 people each would be allowed. This policy would take into effect on July 9th and expire on August 31st.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On July 10, the canton of Bern, Switzerland, tightens the rules for registering guests to clubs and bars so that contact tracing is guaranteed in case of an infection. Business owners of bars, clubs, and dance halls, are required to report the name and address of their establishment to the cantonal medical office, including three additional contact persons. Before admission, guests are required to register with their full name, address, phone number, and email addresses with proof of identity. Business owners/contact persons must be available between 7-10am and ensure that the electronic guest list is sent to the cantonal medical office on request.
type_sub_cat: Bars
institution_status: This type of business  ("Bars") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On 10 Juli the Regierungsrat Kanton Zug decided to add the following restrictions to the national measures: In the interiors of restaurants, including bars and clubs as well as discotheques and dance halls, a maximum of 30 guests may be present at any one time. In the entire guest area of these establishments, including any outdoor areas, a maximum of 100 guests may be present at any one time. The outdoor areas must be clearly recognisable or marked. The contact data must be recorded, regardless of whether the guests enter the interior of the holding or stay only in outside areas ten. 
The decision shall enter into force on 13 July and is in force until 31 August.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: As of Tuesday July 28 in Geneva, Switzerland, customers must wear a mask in shops, as well as by staff when the latter cannot benefit from another protection system (eg glass or plexiglass). The managers of facilities and establishments open to the public must, from Tuesday July 28, 2020, provide their customers with a hydro-alcoholic solution. They must also ensure that no one enters their premises without prior disinfection of the hands. These measures will apply until October 1, 2020, with the possibility of being extended depending on the situation.

description:
From July 31 2020 in Geneva, Switzerland, Customers in bars and restaurants must consume while remaining seated. Interpersonal distances must be respected. This measure is required until 23 August 2020 inclusive and may be extended depending on the epidemiological evolution.

The compulsory mask is now extended to customers of restaurants and bars (including on the terraces) during any movement in the space of the establishment, including for take-out. The client can remove his mask as soon as he is seated.

The operators of bars and similar establishments have the obligation to collect the identity and a reliable means of contact of the customers. 

Violation of these measures may be punished with a fine.
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On August 20, 2020 due to the increasing number of infections, the Government Council of Swiss Canton Basel City decided to make wearing a mask compulsory (effective Monday August 24th) for all publicly accessible indoor areas in sales outlets and shopping centers as well as for the service staff of restaurants and bars. This does not apply to children under the age of 12 or employees protected by a plexiglass pane. First and foremost, certified or compliant masks are recommended. Scarves or other non-specific textiles are not face masks in the present sense.

description:
On March 20th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the reduction of certain administrative functions until further notice. The concerned functions are the following: 
i) Any proceeding that requires a consultation session to be held are being suspended;

ii) For proceedings before special instances of the administrative jurisdiction (as defined by Article 4, clause 2 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings) and before administrative authorities as per Article 3 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings, any notification of decision which is subject to opposition, response or recourse are being held back until 30th April 2020. 

iii) Treatment of demands for popular communal cantonal initiatives, communal initiatives, popular initiatives and optional referenda for communal and cantonal purposes are suspended.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On March 20, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Coucil announced that the following statutory deadlines stand still as of March 21 till may 31:
- Deadline for submitting signature lists for a popular initiative 
- Deadline for the treatment of popular initiatives
- Deadline for the submission of a popular initiative 
The following actions are not carried out during the standstill.
- Disposal of the creation of referenda
- Popular vote on a federal referendum
The collection of signatures is prohibited.

type_sub_cat: Election procedures (e.g. mail-in voting)

description: On March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council ordered an extension of the court holidays in civil and administrative proceedings, which are already imminent for the Easter days. In these proceedings, the court holidays start earlier because of the current emergency. They will now last from March 21 to April 19, 2020. This applies in all proceedings under federal or cantonal law. This does not apply to proceedings in which no court holidays are already planned, in particular in urgent matters and criminal proceedings.

NB: this abrogation is probably related to the federal order closing all non-essential public places on 16th March 2020 (following the declaration of "extraordinary situation").

description: On 25th March 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel suspended all statutory time limits for submitting requests for referenda and popular initiatives on cantonal and communal matters. Moreover, the canton suspended the issuance of certificates of eligibility to vote ("attestation de la qualit d'lecteur") for each request (i.e. the validation of signatures: the administration double-checks that each person who signed the request is eligible to vote and issues a document certifying the number of eligible people who have signed the request). During this suspension, signatures cannot be collected for a prospective petition (referenda or initiatives). The statutory time limits for processing requests is also suspended. All these measures are set to last until 31st May 2020.

description: On March 25, Ticino recommends collecting certain waste, such as masks, tissues, hygiene items, etc. in a separate well-closed plastic bag after their use and then in the municipal waste bag. In the case of sick or quarantined people, separate waste collection is suspended, every waste (including plastic, aluminium, paper, vegetables, etc) has to be put in the same bag. The bag has to be brought by third parties to the collection points, otherwise, the municipality can be contacted.

description:
In Switzerland, the canton Aargau decided that the deadline for submitting the tax return 2019 is extended until June 30 for employed people and until September 30, 2020 for self-employed people and farmers.
The deadline for submitting the 2019 tax return for legal entities will be extended until September 30, 2020. There is no need to submit a deadline extension.
For tax claims, a reminder and debt enforcement stop applies until June 30, 2020.
Official deadlines set by the tax authorities for the submission of additional documents can be extended upon request. The tax authorities treat such requests with goodwill.
From March 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020, in the event of late payment of the cantonal and municipal tax due in this period, no default interest is due.

If a company is bankrupt or must close because of corona, a provision can be made in the 2019 annual financial statements.

The Department of Finance and Resources can deviate from legal deadlines in cases of liquidity shortage and difficulties in complying with procedural obligations with the tax law.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached

description:

description:
From the 2nd of April on there will be public social assistance prevention measures. Accordingly, the regulations for responsibilities for case management and assistance changed.
If a municipal or regional social service is unable to perform its duties the municipality has to provide a temporary solution. 
If they cant, the cantonal social service can temporarily transfer responsibility for case management and assistance to another local/ regional social service or another suitable agency.
It takes over the case management and assistance in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in its municipality, if this one is not able to fulfill its duties another appropriate body takes over.
The original municipality has to bear the expenses incurred by the newly responsible institution.
The cantonal social service can take appropriate coordination measures and regulate uniform criteria for assuming responsibility in an instruction.

Requests for the granting of cost credits for medical purposes that do not tolerate a delay are to be treated as appropriate and the associated payments as quickly as possible to do.

The cantonal social service can oblige the municipal and regional social services to take over the management of the case for the duration of the ongoing jurisdictional procedure.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:

From the 2nd of April on there will be public social assistance prevention measures. Accordingly, the regulations for responsibilities for case management and assistance changed.
If a municipal or regional social service is unable to perform its duties the municipality has to provide a temporary solution. 
If they cant, the cantonal social service can temporarily transfer responsibility for case management and assistance to another regional social service or another suitable agency.
It would take over the case management and assistance in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in its municipality, if this one is not able to fulfill its duties another appropriate body takes over.
The original municipality must bear the expenses incurred by the newly responsible institution.
The cantonal social service can take appropriate coordination measures and regulate uniform criteria for assuming responsibility in an instruction.

Requests for the granting of cost credits for medical purposes that do not tolerate a delay are to be treated as appropriate and the associated payments as quickly as possible to do.

The cantonal social service can oblige the municipal and regional social services to take over the management of the case for the duration of the ongoing jurisdictional procedure

description:
In Switzerland, the canton Aargau decided at the from the 2nd of April on the responsible official authority of the building and inspection law regulations can determine while the SonderV 20-1 is active the files to be issued can be requested in paper form as well as electronically

The responsible official authority can state that files have to be inspected digitally and that only after an agreement files can be inspected in the responsible office when well-founded instructions will be followed.

The responsible authority is empowered to extend the official deadline for public disclosures process by 30 days

In the event of a lack of urgency in time, the responsible authority can provide for the public disclosure process for a later date.

description:
In Switzerland, the cantonal parliament of Aargau has made the necessary preparations so that the plenary council can meet again and fulfill its constitutional task. The parliament will meet externally in order to comply with the necessary safety precautions and distance rules.

Spreitenbach environmental arena

Depending on the situation assessment, if necessary, further cantonal parliament meetings will be held in June 2020 in the Spreitenbach environmental arena. 

The cantonal parliament meetings are public according to the cantonal constitution. The media can attend the meeting on May 12, 2020. Guests can follow the session from a separate gallery. The number of places is limited. In exceptional cases, media representatives and visitors must register with the parliamentary service in advance. The registration form is published on the Internet

This includes the Engadin Skimarathon. Non-compliance is to be fined.

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.

This is intended to implement federal restrictions on mass gatherings.

This does not apply to events with official participants from affected areas (definition FOPH, status March 4, 2020: China, Iran, South Korea, Singapore, and in Italy Lombardy, Piedmont and Veneto).
Events with more than 1000 participants are banned by the Federal Government.

In Switzerland the canton of Aargau decided that from the 28th of February to the 15th of March events with 150 to 999 people will have to file a request that has to be authorized by the Kantonsrztliche Dienst (KAD) (cantonal office of health) of the canton of Aargau.

Switzerland, The canton Glarus said on February 28th 2020, that mass gatherings with a number below 1000 participants are allowed, when no one is tested positive on the corona virus. Before that the Swiss federal government announced that mass gatherings with more then 1000 participants are prohibited

On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Uri announced that according to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 persons and the requirement of an cantonal risk assessment for smaller events, the cantonal special staff Corona ( "Sonderstab Corona") carried out a basic assessment for events in Uri:
Outdoor events, normal operation in restaurants, public transport, family events or events with participants knowing each other will not be restricted. All other events must be subjected to a risk assessment by the cantonal special staff corona.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On February 28, the government of Schwyz announced public and private events may take place if there are less than 1000 people. This will be valid until at least March 15, 2020.

On February 28th the Canton of Luzern, Switzerland bans events with foreign participation from crisis areas. All other events have to be announced to the cantonal authorities and will undergo a risk assessment.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description:
On February 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that according to the federal ban on public or private events that are attended by more than 1,000 people that in Solothurn a restrictive risk assessment is carried out for events with 100 to 999 participants.
Criteria such as:
    Provide clear information to participants and employees about measures to reduce the risk of transmission (general hygiene measures, coronavirus information for travelers returning, etc.)
    Avoid participation of sick people
    Avoid participation by anyone who has been in an affected area in the past 14 days
    Ensure traceability of participants
    Composition of the audience with regard to risk groups
As a matter of principle, the special staff recommends avoiding events of this size. In any case, the organizer is obliged to consult with the canton for an implementation. A risk assessment is carried out via the hotline (0800 112 117).
 In the case of events with up to 100 people taking part, the organizers are responsible for deciding on the implementation.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Swiss canton Zurich implements the national prohibition of mass gatherings; not more than 1000 people may meet. All events below that mass may take place without any special permission from March 4.

On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State immediately and until March 15 prohibits events and gatherings bringing together a number of people greater than 500 in a closed or confined space.

On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. 
An evaluation questionnare will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
        the importance of the event
        the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
        the confinement of the premises
        the type of activities planned

Swiss canton Zurich recommends all members of risk groups to stay away from any event on March 4. These are: People over 65, with high blood pressure, diabetes, heart- circuit problems, chronic respiratory diseases, illnesses or therapies weakening the immune system, cancer.
On March 4th, the Canton of Luzern, Switzerland declares that all events with less than 1000 participants have to be recorded via an online form

The Swiss canton of St. Gallen decided, on March 5, that organizers of events with 150-999 people have to fill out a form online. The Department of Health then decides on the risks of the event and if it is allowed. For events with under 150 people the organizer must carry out a risk assessment themselves.

type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 5th, 2020, the canton of Appenzell-Innerrhoden has announced that organizers of mass gatherings and events of 150-1000 people shall get in touch with cantonal health authorities to assess potential risks of events in spreading Covid-19.

type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 6, the Swiss Canton of Freiburg released a protocol on the by the federal government announced restriction of mass gatherings of more than 1000 people. The protocol outlines conditions of necessary hygiene measures, participation of vulnerable persons, and the special investigation of events of more than 150 participants.

On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Health of Canton Grisons specified its order concerning mass gathering. Prohibited are outdoor events with more than 500 persons, indoor events with more than 300 seated persons (except there are more than 4 squaremeter per person) or indoor events with more than 150 freely circulating persons. All other events have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal administration. Non-compliance is to be fined.

On March 6, the Swiss Canton of Freiburg released a protocol on the by the federal government announced restriction of mass gatherings of more than 1000 people. The protocol outlines conditions of necessary hygiene measures, participation of vulnerable persons, and the special investigation of events of more than 150 participants. On March 16, this policy was succeeded by tightened measures.

description: On march 6,2020 the swiss canton Ticino is banning mass gathering with more than 150 persons after march 7, 2020 till march 15, 2020.

The Swiss federal government announced that events with more then 1000 persons are prohibited. The authorities of the canton Schaffhausen said as a reaction to this federal policy that events with less then 1000 persons are still allowed on February 28th 2020.

on March 11, 2020 the Swiss Canton of Geneva banned public or private events with more than 100 participants. Excepeted are events with less than 1000 paricipants seated with a guaranteed spacing of 1 or 1.5 m without a side activity ( apro, bar ). It is recommended to notify the event at the cantonal medical service.
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: on march 11, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is limiting mass gatherings and events to 50 persons after march 12.
The health ministry on Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland recommends, not to attend any event on March 13.

The canton Glarus announced that mass gatherings and events with more then 100 participants are prohibited. Mass gatherings with less then 100 participants are allowed when certain measurements of hygiene are being followed. Those measurements are that people with Covid-19 symptoms shouldn't visit mass gatherings, people over the age of 65 shouldn't attend mass gatherings, all people should be informed about hygiene and confined spaces should be avoided.
On March 13th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that all gatherings above 100 people were forbidden until April 4th. For restaurants, bars and clubs, the limit was set to 50.

On March 13, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Valais prohibited all public or private events involving more than 50 people starting March 13.
Sporting and cultural activities and group events, both professional and amateur athletes, of every type and category, regardless of the number of people present were prohibited.
It was recommend to authorities, companies and others to refrain from all activities, events and meetings in which fewer than 50 people take part.

At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.
This policy was abrogated already on March 13.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Swiss federal government announced that events with more then 1000 persons are prohibited. The authorities of the canton Schaffhausen said as a reaction to this federal policy that events with less then 1000 persons are still allowed on February 28th 2020.

On March 13, 2020 Swiss Canton Geneva has announced that the decree of the Council of State of March 11, 2020 relating to mass gatherings on the territory of the Republic and canton of Geneva is repealed with immediate effect.
Noting that  Ordinance 2 COVID-19 decreed by the federal council on March 13 provides for more restrictive measures than those decreed by the Council of State of the Republic and canton of Geneva.
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:

NB: this abrogation is probably related to federal prohibition of all mass gatherings on 20th March 2020

description:
On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. 
An evaluation questionnare will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
        the importance of the event
        the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
        the confinement of the premises
        the type of activities planned
This policy was ended on March 15 by another cantonal policy banning all mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except necessary meetings of maximum 20 people.

Switzerland, Geneva--Beginning March 16, gatherings of more than 5 are are prohibited both inside and outside. Professional gatherings can still occur if there is respect to guidelines outlined by the Federal Office of Public Health.

On March 15, the Swiss Canton Grisons announces the suspension of all religious gatherings. Burials may only be held in the closest family circle. The policy enters into force on March 16 until April 30.

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation and exceptions can be granted for events of public interest (e.g. gatherings to exercise political rights) which require the prior submission of a preventive concept.
Basel Landschaft (Switzerland) prohibits any gatherings with more than 50 people from March 16 until April 30 except there is a huge public interest (eg exercise of political rights).

On March 16th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the cancellation of the "Semaine de la langue franaise et de la francophonie" ("Week of the French language and francophony") due to COVID-19 restrictions.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. This policy was later changed to a maximum of 5 people from March 20. The cantonal policy of mass gatherings ended on June 8, when the Canton complied with the federal decisions on mass gatherings.

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation and exceptions can be granted for events of public interest (e.g. gatherings to exercise political rights) which require the prior submission of a preventive concept. From March 17, the Canton increased police presence to enforce the policies.

At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to.
This policy ended prematurely on March 16.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Swiss federal government prohibits mass gatherings of more then five persons, which affects the canton Glarus. People who violate this policy have to pay a fine. Furthermore companys which work on construction sites have to ensure, that their employees have to hold on to hygiene rules and social distancing. Companys have to limit the number of employees on a construction site so that social distancing is guaranteed.
On 20th of March the Uri Kanton government decided to cancel all direct elections, petition for a referendum and a restrictions of accompanying collections of signatures etc.

description: March 20 Federal Council prohibits the gathering of more than five people

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. On March 20, the policy was strengthened to gatherings of more than 5 people, while no end date was included in the policy protocol anymore. Penalties of 100-150 Swiss Francs for individuals, and 2000-5000 Francs for businesses, and legal prosecution were also announced for a breach of the measures.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On March 21, Switzerland,  Ticino prohibits all organized or spontaneous gatherings with more than five people. Violations of the prohibitions can be punished with a disciplinary fine of CHF 100.-

On March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council banned gathering of more than five people in public as of March 21st. Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
As before (start March 17, 2020) all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), funerals in close family circle, playing children (in  groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms.

On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council banned all public or private events, including parties, sports events, political demonstrations and General assemblies as of March 17.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups ( in public spaces and at home), playing children (recommended group size 5) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4qm in closed rooms. This was scheduled to end April 19th.
On April 8th the Federal Council decided to extend the ban on events and gatherings by one week till April 26th.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
On 22nd April 2020, the state council of the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to ban all mass gatherings bringing together several hundreds of people up until 21st June 2020 at the earliest. 

NB: this policy echoes the "deconfinement plan" released by the Swiss Federal Council on 16th April 2020, which reaffirms the ban on mass gatherings but doesn't give any end date to this ban. The Neuchtel state council specified in their news release that they were giving the date of 21st June 2020 to clarify the situation and give more visibility to event organizers.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On 24th April 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to postpone to 2021 the cross-cultural festival NeuchToi, which was supposed to occur from 30th August to 30th October 2020. A new date hasn't been set yet for this annually recurring event which should have celebrated its 5th year in 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On April 24, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Jura announced that the holding of municipal assemblies, meetings of general councils or city councils remain suspended. These meetings and sessions may resume from May 25, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description:
On March 17th the Canton Uri released an instruction to clarify how the measures by the federal government  are being implemented in the Canton. First it is a restriction of mass gatherings forbidding all social events or amusment/leisure businesses (as theaters, cinemas, museums, concerts...). Groups are supposed to have max. 5 people. 

April 23rd. 
Churches are allowed to open, but no services or events are allowed. Everything else stays closed (e.g. cinemas) or forbidden. (e.g. partys)
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description:
On April 16, 2020 at its meeting the Swiss Federal Council decided the next steps for gradually easing measures against coronavirus after April 27. The restriction whereby funerals may only be attended by close family will also be lifted as of April 27th, provided a protection concept complying to the guidelines of the Federal Office of Health.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till May 10th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), playing children (in groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms, funerals.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description: On 29 April, the Federal Council decided that measures to combat coronavirus in the area of sport would also be relaxed as of 11 May. From 11 May, sports training will be possible again under certain conditions, both in popular and competitive sport. The federal government's hygiene regulations must be strictly adhered to and appropriate protection concepts are necessary. The umbrella associations of the individual sports provide sample concepts for this purpose. The Canton of Zug will carry out spot checks on clubs and sports facility operators and support them in implementing the requirements.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description:
On April 29, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on the next steps to relax the measures against the coronavirus. From May 11th, sports clubs can resume training for amateur athletes in groups of five and without physical contact and with more exceptions for competitive athletes (permanent teams). Markets can take place.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, other club activities, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings (limited to 1 person per 4 qm), funerals (in a family-closed friends-circle), training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, markets.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. From May 19, the cantonal leadership body (KFO) decided to exempt meetings of club directorates from the restriction of mass gatherings of no more than 5 people.

description:
On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden.

On May 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced  that faith communities should be able to resume their common religious life. From the 28th of May 2020, all services and celebrations of all faiths will once again be permitted. The religious communities have one week to work out protection concepts and to ensure the tracing of possible chains of infection. A framework protection concept has been drawn up by the Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH).

description:
On May 27, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on further easing the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus starting May 30. 
Till and including May 29 gathering of more than five people in public is  banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings, training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, amateur sports in groups of five, markets, religious services and celebrations including funerals (protection concept).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
On May 27th, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council decided: The ban on gatherings in public, in particular in public spaces, promenades and parks is to be eased. As of 30 May, the upper limit will be increased from 5 to 30 people.
Gathering in groups over 30 persons can be fined, not adhering to social distancing rules is no longer to be fined. Nevertheless social distancing remains highly recommended. Exempted are school children at school playgrounds.

On April 24,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura announced that the suspension in effect of known time limits on political rights will end on May 31, 2020, as at the federal level. Voting and elections may in particular resume from June 1 st .

description: On June 3, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden announced that contrary to its prior announcement, it would hold a high school graduation ceremony, albeit in a reduced form following strict hygiene measures.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description:
On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that 
from June 6th, private and public events with up to 300 people are to be allowed.This includes family events, fairs, concerts, club activities, sports events/competitions, theatre performances and film screenings, general assemblies,as well as political and civil society demonstrations.
On condition that all events have appropriate sets of precautionary measures in place. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, by means of attendance lists, for example. 
Summer holiday camps for children and young people will be allowed to go ahead from 6 June as long as appropriate sets of precautionary measures are in place. Children and young people should remain in the same groups wherever possible. The upper limit for camps is 300 people and organisers must keep an attendance list.
Cantons can allow exemptions for important reasons. Non-public events ( family events, club activities where people know each other) with less than 30 persons only have to ensure contact tracing.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced that private mass gatherings of up to 300 people (in compliance with the 6th June 2020 federal policy allowing mass gatherings up to 300 people) can be organized without a protection plan (i.e. a document to be submitted to the canton), but hygiene and social distancing measures have to be respected. If they can't be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by collecting the personal data (names, phone numbers) of participants.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel announced that private mass gatherings of up to 300 people (in compliance with the 6th June 2020 federal policy allowing mass gatherings up to 300 people) can be organized without a protection plan (i.e. a document to be submitted to the canton), but hygiene and social distancing measures have to be respected. If they can't be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by collecting the personal data (names, phone numbers) of participants.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel specified the details of the mandatory protection plan for all public mass gatherings between 30 and 300 people. The organizer of the event will have to submit an application to the Department of Consumption and Veterinary Affairs specifying the name of the person in charge of the Covid safety measures. If the 2 meters social distancing cannot be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by listing the names and phone numbers of participants; this data shall be stored for 14 days and made available to the government if need be.

NB: this policy follows on from the federal government's announcement on 6th June 2020 that mass gatherings up to 300 people could be organized in Switzerland, as long as they have a protection plan.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that 
from June 6th, private and public events with up to 300 people are to be allowed.
Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, by means of attendance lists, for example. 
Summer holiday camps for children and young people will be allowed to go ahead from 6 June as long as appropriate sets of precautionary measures are in place.The upper limit for camps is 300 people
Spontaneous gathering in public spaces remain restricted to 30 persons. Cantons can allow exemptions for important reasons. On June 19 th, 2020 the Federal Council decided that political demonstrations are no longer limited by number of pariticipants as of June 20, but masks wearing is compulsory at demonstrations.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Basel-Landschaft (Switzerland) restricts public and private events to 100 participants, otherwise divisions in sectors of 100 persons each are to be carried out from July 8.

description: On July 8th, the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that public and private events for 101 to 1000 people would have to be conducted in seperate rooms for a maximum of 100 people each. This number excludes active participants (e.g. actors, artists). Furthermore, event organizers would have to identify, record and verify contact data of all visitors. This policy was scheduled to take into effect on July 9th and expire on August 31st.

description: On July 8, 2020, the Swiss canton of Basel City announced that despite a federal limit of 300 people per sector on public and private events, it would lower this limit to 100 if social distancing and other protective measures cannot be guaranteed.

description:
On 10 Juli the Regierungsrat Kanton Zug decided to add the following restrictions to the national measures: In the interiors of restaurants, including bars and clubs as well as discotheques and dance halls, a maximum of 30 guests may be present at any one time. In the entire guest area of these establishments, including any outdoor areas, a maximum of 100 guests may be present at any one time. The outdoor areas must be clearly recognisable or marked. The contact data must be recorded, regardless of whether the guests enter the interior of the holding or stay only in outside areas ten. 
The decision shall enter into force on 13 July and is in force until 31 August.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

In this case, closed sectors with a maximum of 100 people need to be established.

On July 17, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of up to 300 persons for non-political and non-commercial gatherings. Exceptions can be requested alongside the submission of a prevention and hygiene concept. Religious gatherings and funerals will equally require a hygiene concept.

description: On July 16, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the measures implemented on July 3, i.e. the restrictions of mass gatherings up to 30 persons and the limitation of 100 customers in bars and restaurants, until August 9.

On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation

From Saturday, August 22nd onwards, events for 100 people or more may only be held if the minimum distance can be maintained or masks are worn. In return, up to 100 people are again allowed in the indoor areas of clubs and bars at the same time, so that the same rules apply to all establishments and events.
In Zurich (Switzerland) events with over 100 participants must provide a safety concept from August 24.
On August 24th, the Plenary session of the Canton of Vaud Grand Council was delayed from August 24th until the 28th as a means to ensure a stop to a small outbreak in the chamber.

description:
At its meeting on August 12, the Swiss Federal Council took the decision to extend the ban on large scale events with more than 1000 persons till September 30. Large-scale events will be permitted from October under strict conditions and with a permit by cantonal authorities.
This gives the cantons time to prepare the permit system and increase their contact tracing capacities, if necessary.

description:
On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden.
Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland) cancells the annual animal schows ("Viehschauen") from mid-september to mid-october 2020 on July 7.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On September 24, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri issued its guidelines for the approval of mass events (over 1000 participants) based on federal guidelines, effective from October 1. Organizers must submit an application in advance and outline a hygiene concept. Visitors of an event must be seated on personalised spots, social distancing and hygiene must be ensured at all times, and there must be a procedure to handle suspected cases. Events can only be approved if the number of infections s low enough and the capacities for contact tracing at the local authorities are ensured. Permits can be revoked if any of the aforementioned conditions is no longer met.

In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low and the canton has sufficient capacities for contact tracing: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least six weeks in advance except for events before November 8, which can be approved at shorter notice. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, seats must be assigned to specific individuals, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.

In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Obwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least one month in advance except for events in October, where the deadline is 10 days before the scheduled date. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.
The swiss canton Valais implements a restriction of gatherings to 50 people from October 18 2020.
The swiss canton Valais implements a restriction of gatherings to 50 people from October 18 2020. The policy ends due to a national policy on October 19.
The swiss canton Valais prohibits any events with more than 10 people in public and private areas from October 22.

Beginning on October 22, all public or private events in the canton of Solothurn are limited to 50 people excluding performers and other staff/organizers, unless social distancing or other protective measures can be ensured
On October 23, the Swiss canton of Solothurn announced a complete ban on all events over 1000 participants until January 31. Permits for such events that have been issued are revoked.

The canton of Uri decided to limit the annual event 'Landeswallfahrt' ('state pilgrimage') on October 24, 2020 to a small event attended by some high-level government officials and clergy from the canton.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description: On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel decided to postpone the municipal election ("lections communales") that was supposed to take place on 14th June 2020. A new date for the election is still to be chosen and discussed with the municipalities in the canton. On 4th May 2020, the state council of the Canton of Neuchtel chose 25th October 2020 as the new date for the election, thus ending the original policy.

description: Beginning on October 22, all public or private events in the canton of Solothurn are limited to 50 people excluding performers and other staff/organizers, unless social distancing or other protective measures can be ensured

description: The Swiss Federal Council asks that all residents comply with social distancing regulations, including no meetings of more than five people and a complete vacation of public spaces e.g. parks from March 20th onwards.

On March 20, 2020:
Because people have not being fully complying with the rules on social distancing the Swiss Federal Council has decided that in public places people must keep a distance of at least two metres from each other starting March 21 till April 19. The police may impose a fine for non-compliance.

Valais (Switzerland) recommends all citizens on March 24 to conduct necessary outgoings at locations and times where people are as isolated as possible and distance to others is respected as well as to stay at the balkony in the sun to minimize the risk of infection. If people seem to be infected, they should contact their doctor via phone first to reduce people staying in doctors offices.

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to temporarily change the regulation on electronic signatures. The change provides a general way of video identification when issuing certificates, making physical signatures redundant. This way, trips and personal contacts can be avoided
On April 2nd the city of Luzern, Switzerland closes a number of public spaces as people do not adhere to Social Distancing

The Swiss Federal Council has made adjustments to the asylum procedure in Switzerland which is to be coordinated across all cantons from April 1st 2020. The changes include greater physical distance in the asylum interview process (fewer individuals in the room etc) and additional accommodation for asylum applicants who are unable to leave due to COVID-19 to be made by converting military accommodation.
The Thurgau government asks residents to stay at home despite the nice weather over the Easter period in a plea to continue social distancing on April 8th 2020.

The Canton of Zug urges its population to avoid travel over Easter and avoid popular outdoor areas such as the lake shore and hiking paths in order to comply with federal measures, the police will be deployed to ensure compliance, on April 8th 2020.

description: On May 7, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg published a press release recommending the wearing of masks, and showing the right use of one, as an additional measure for situations where in public places the social distancing and hygiene measures cannot be complied with. Specifically mentioned are public transport and shops, while an emphasis is placed on the continuous respect of other hygiene measures even when a mask is worn.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside private businesses (e.g. supermarkets)

description:
Switzerland, Geneva--Traffic restrictions will go into place throughout the canton from May 9 until May 10. Access will be limited to residents and certain car parks will be closed in these areas: 
Centre sportif des Evaux
Signal de Bernex
Mandement / AIIondon
Centre sportif de Vessy
Centre sportif du Bout-du-Monde
Plage du Vengeron
Plage du Reposoir
Port Choiseul
Sentier du promeneur solitaire
Sentier des Falaises
Moulin-des-Frres
Bord de l'Arve
Bord du Rhne (barrage de Verbois / Moulin-de-Vert)
Bois de la Btie (parc animalier et place de jeux)
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On 8th June 2020, the RHNe (Neuchtel hospital network) of the Swiss Canton of Neuchtel announced that from 9th June 2020 on, all visitors had to wear a mask while visiting their relatives in hospital and that they had to keep a distance of at least 1 meter apart from the patients.

description:
On June 19, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that there is no upper limit for the number of people able to attend a demonstration, but it will be mandatory to wear a face mask. This change concerning political and civil society demonstrations will apply from Saturday, 20 June.
Gathering of less than 30 persons are excepted from mask obligation.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The canton of Bern, Switzerland, announces on 30 June that masks will be mandatory in prisons. This includes both prisoners and prison staff. Prisoners must wear masks any time they are outside of their cells.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On 3rd July 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel strongly recommended wearing a mask in businesses and stores. It also indicated that this policy could become mandatory in case Covid-19 cases rose again in the canton.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy

description: On 3rd July 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchtel strongly recommended wearing a mask in businesses and stores. The canton indicated that this recommendation could become mandatory if Covid-19 cases in Neuchtel were to increase again.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy

description: On 3rd July 2020, the Swiss canton of Jura announced that wearing a mask in stores and businesses would be mandatory from 6th July 2020 on and for a duration of 2 months (until 6th September). Only children below 12 years old are not concerned by this policy and are allowed not to wear a mask.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
At its meeting on 1 July, the SwissFederal Council has decided to make masks compulsory on public transport throughout the country from Monday, 6 July. Persons over the age of 12 will have to wear a mask in trains, trams and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.
An urgent recommendation is already in place to wear a mask when travelling on public transport at peak times.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy

description:
The Federal Council has decided on July 1st that as of July 6th travelers in public transport must wear a face mask in all vehicles. This now also applies to aircraft as of August 12ve.
This does not apply to: a. Children before their 12th birthday; b. People who can prove that they are unable to wear face masks for special reasons, particularly medical ones.
The measure affects all scheduled and charter flights that take off or land in Switzerland, regardless of the airline.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On July 14, the Swiss Canton Grisons advises against using plastic visors only as they give a false sense of security. If the distance of 1.5 meters cannot be maintained, face masks or other suitable measures are recommended. With regard to the summer season, companies that have previously relied on the protection of plastic visors are recommended to revise their protection concepts.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside private businesses (e.g. supermarkets)

description:
On August 5, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Education in Canton Basel-City anounced that after summer break ( August 10th)  the "Mittelschulen" ( upper secondary age above 15) and vocational schools are faced with the challenge of complying with the distance rules by the Federal Office of Health. Where this is not possible, masks and plexiglass solutions can be used.
Schools made extensive changes in the classrooms in order to enable teaching in full classes.This also includes the purchase of additional individual desks. In this way, a general mask requirement can be avoided during lessons. A mask requirement should only exist where the distances cannot be maintained, e.g. practical training, in training workshops, in laboratory lessons.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On August 20, 2020 due to the increasing number of infections, the Government Council of Swiss Canton Basel City decided to make wearing a mask compulsory (effective Monday August 24th) on the school premises of upper secondary schools (age above 15 years) and higher education institutions. Since the safety distance can be maintained in the classrooms of upper secondary schools, lessons continue to take place without masks. First and foremost, certified or compliant masks are recommended. Scarves or other non-specific textiles are not face masks in the present sense.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Beginning on September 3, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn requires the wearing of face masks in all retail stores and shopping centers. Exempt are children under the age of 12, people who must not wear a mask for medical reasons (if carrying a written certificate by a doctor), as well as staff, if protected by a physical barrier.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy
